**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter and parties pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28** and **G.L. c. 215, § 6**, as the original custody judgment was entered in this Court and the minor children reside within its jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Rachel Thompson, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Massachusetts Rules of Domestic Relations Procedure, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody and parenting-time order entered on **May 15, 2020**, by the **Bristol County Probate and Family Court**, on the grounds that a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred since the entry of said judgment, and that modification is in the best interests of the minor children, **Emily Johnson (age 8)** and **Noah Johnson (age 6)**.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter and parties pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28** and **G.L. c. 215, § 6**, as the original custody judgment was entered in this Court and the minor children reside within its jurisdiction.

See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 1.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a Probate and Family Court may modify a custody or parenting plan judgment upon a finding that (a) a **material and substantial change in circumstances** has occurred, and (b) the proposed modification is in the **best interests of the child**.
See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a relocation/removal case decided under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general modification-of-custody case under § 28. The court’s analysis focuses on the meaning of “upon cause shown” in § 30 and applies a best-interests standard in that specific statutory context; it does not discuss or set out the § 28 standard of ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ plus best interests as the test for modification of custody or parenting plans. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition about § 28.
See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 1.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 368.proposition: The “material change” requirement ensures stability but allows flexibility when circumstances affecting the child’s welfare evolve.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 368.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly articulates the requirement of a “material change of circumstances” for modification of alimony or child support and emphasizes stability by denying modification absent such a change. However, it does not explicitly frame that requirement as a doctrine designed to ensure stability while also allowing flexibility when circumstances affecting the child’s welfare evolve. The case focuses more on whether a change has occurred and on the obligor’s ability to pay than on describing the broader policy balance between stability and flexibility in child welfare terms.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 368.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. Resolution of the issue rests in the judge’s sound discretion. … [A] substantial decrease in income or financial status may warrant a modification, such a decrease does not alone compel a modification.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..raw_text: *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The overarching inquiry remains the welfare and best interests of the child.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that, under the removal statute, the central question is how the child’s “best interests” are to be determined, and emphasizes that the best interests of the child are the paramount concern. It explains that all relevant factors (including the custodial parent’s interests) are weighed only insofar as they bear on the child’s welfare. This directly supports the proposition that the overarching inquiry remains the welfare and best interests of the child.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: In determining whether modification is necessary, courts consider the child’s safety and the ability of each parent to provide a stable and secure environment.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The case discusses standards for initial custody determinations, emphasizing the children’s best interests, welfare, happiness, and stability of their environment, but it does not address modification of custody or support orders. While the opinion notes factors like the primary nurturing parent, emotional bonds, and minimizing disruption, it never frames these as criteria specifically for deciding whether a later modification is ‘necessary.’ Thus, it supports a general best‑interests/stability principle, not the specific proposition about modification determinations.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A**.proposition: When evidence arises of violence or unsafe domestic conditions, Massachusetts courts must act to protect children from potential harm. See **G.L. c. 208, § 31A** (requiring consideration of domestic violence); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 596 (1996); *Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882, 886 (1997).

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 596.raw_text: *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 596 (1996); *Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882, 886 (1997).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 596.proposition: When evidence arises of violence or unsafe domestic conditions, Massachusetts courts must act to protect children from potential harm. See **G.L. c. 208, § 31A** (requiring consideration of domestic violence); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 596 (1996); *Adoption of Quentin*, 424 Mass. 882, 886 (1997).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 596.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the obligation of Massachusetts courts, in custody matters, to consider domestic violence and its effects on children. The SJC holds that domestic violence is “too fundamental” to be handled implicitly and requires explicit findings on how such violence affects the child and the appropriateness of any custody award, citing and reinforcing statutory requirements. This directly supports the proposition that when evidence of violence or unsafe domestic conditions arises, courts must act—through findings and custody determinations—to protect children from potential harm.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 596.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’… Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.raw_text: *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840–41 (2003); *Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.proposition: The Court’s paramount consideration is always the child’s best interests, even over parental preferences.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reiterates the long-standing Massachusetts rule that in custody matters “the best interests of the child” is the paramount concern, citing earlier authority including Care & Protection of Three Minors. It explains that this standard replaced the older, more parent-centered view of children as parental property and requires courts to treat the child’s welfare as the controlling consideration, even where parents have competing claims or preferences. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition that the court’s paramount consideration is always the child’s best interests over parental preferences.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt…; Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962)… (‘most fundamental [principle] is that the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’).”

*Roe v. Roe*, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 382 (200.proposition: The requirement that modifications be “material” ensures that the court does not reopen judgments lightly but responds appropriately to serious changes in circumstances.
*Roe v. Roe*, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 382 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion in Roe v. Roe as excerpted here is about a general contractor’s duty and control over jobsite safety in a negligence case; it does not discuss modification of judgments, material changes in circumstances, or standards for reopening prior judgments. Because the court never addresses any doctrine of ‘material’ modifications or their gatekeeping function for reopening judgments, it cannot be cited as authority for that proposition.
*Roe v. Roe*, 73 Mass. App. Ct. 382 (200.relevant_excerpt: No portion of the provided opinion text refers to modification of judgments or ‘material’ changes in circumstances; it addresses only negligence, duty, and control on a construction site.

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The presence of a cohabitant with a history of violence constitutes a material change in circumstances justifying review of custody or parenting time.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not address cohabitation with a violent partner or any history of violence as a factor in custody or parenting time. The material-change analysis concerns the mother’s relocation, work schedule, extended family ties, and a temporary custody order, and the court ultimately holds that these circumstances did not justify modifying custody. Nothing in the reasoning establishes or discusses the rule that the presence of a cohabitant with a history of violence constitutes a material change in circumstances.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’ Tolos v. Tolos, 11 Mass. App. Ct. 708, 710-711 (1981) (citation omitted).”

**G.L. c. 209A**.proposition: The presence of a cohabitant with a history of violence constitutes a material change in circumstances justifying review of custody or parenting time.
